It's similar to college admissions that use affirmative action. They will not say it outright but they use internal quotas to limit the number of white/asian applicants they take in. According to a staff engineer I know at Google, there have been cases where the engineer interviewing the applicant was told to give "lighter" questions because of the applicant's "diverse" background.
Damn, guess I gotta really push hard that i'm a POC then

To be clear, as per Prop 209, Regents of the University of California v. Bakke, Fisher v. University of Texas, etc. use of affirmative action and quotas are illegal in college admissions. Please don't undermine your peer's accomplishments or place here at UC Berkeley by assuming they were admitted because of their various identities.

Hey Nicole, sorry I know this is a sensitive subject but it was not my intent to undermine or hurt anyone. However racial quotas in college admissions are a real thing in private universities such as Harvard, Yale, etc. Harvard is literally being sued for actively discriminating against Asian-Americans (https://www.nytimes.com/2018/10/15/us/harvard-affirmative-action-asian-americans.html). Asian-Americans applicants were consistently rated lower than whites or other racial groups in the "personality rating" portion of their evaluation for candidates, even with all other things equal. The evidence heavily suggests that Harvard and other private universities have implicit quotas on Asian-Americans, and are using the guise of holistic admissions to deny them entry.

^

Harvard is racist. Harvard is racist. Harvard is racist.

So many young Asians I know have at some point bought into this myth that Asians (especially the guys) have inferior personalities because of the gap between achievement and college acceptance, and it's done serious damage to their mental health. They don't think of the possibility that Harvard might be racist - "they're a liberal institution, how can they be racist?" Their "personality ratings" show that - either they're using the rating to enforce racial quotas, which is illegal, or they're just straight up racist. Not really sure which is worse for them - they're trying to deny both.

Here's a great podcast about the Harvard case: https://planamag.com/escape-from-plan-a-ep-60-hey-harvard-just-be-honest-835ee885ca5e

I agree. Many Asians are too blind to the issues they face as a community. From the casual racism they face everyday to the obvious racial quotas imposed on them, they are too complacent with what's going on. You look at Hollywood films and Asian men are dehumanized and Asian women hypersexualized/fetishized, being portrayed in the worst ways imaginable. Many are surprised when they experience blatant discrimination/racism for the first time. Unfortunately as China overtakes the US, the racism and xenophobia against Asians will only get worse.

Also to Nicole, just because it's illegal to use affirmative action in UC doesn't mean it's impossible that discrimination may have happened. Case in point, https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/education/actors-designers-distillery-owners-here-are-some-of-those-charged-in-the-college-admissions-scheme/2019/03/12/3c2f5316-4500-11e9-8aab-95b8d80a1e4f_story.html?utm_term=.e685f9cb0582. That being said, we have no proof here in UC Berkeley. Cal also uses holistic admissions too, so it's not impossible, as unfortunate as it may be. But I'll leave it at here - my intention is NOT to induce paranoia or create a conspiracy.
Asking out of curiosity not to agree or disagree with your thoughts, which companies have been told to cap number of white and asian male applicants?

Hey Nick, I’ll bite. My impression is that almost everyone supports sourcing candidate from as many avenues as possible (this includes “less prestigious” colleges, HBCUs, bootcamps, etc) as long as the hiring standard isn’t lowered for anyone. Companies outwardly promote this view of their hiring practices.

 

I’m only going to comment only on this view, not the view that some candidates should get preferential treatment based on lived or historical discrimination.

There are two mechanisms that I know of which seem to lower standards for certain applicants.

 

1. Application purges

 

In April of 2017, Google’s Technology Stafﬁng Management team was instructed by Alogna to immediately cancel all Level 3 (0-5 years experience) software engineering interviews with every single applicant who was not either female, Black, or Hispanic and to purge entirely any applications by non-diverse employees from the hiring pipeline. Plaintiff refused to comply with this request.

 

From https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2018/03/ex-google-recruiter-i-was-fired-because-i-resisted-illegal-diversity-efforts/

 

Given that the plaintiffs refusal to comply with the request in this article aggravated all his coworkers, we can only conclude that this isn’t an isolated incidence. I’ve heard of another such purge of non POC applicants from one other anecdotal source (not for entry-level positions). I have no idea how widespread this is, just pointing it out.

 

2. Grace hopper style interviews

 

This is more obvious. Basically *some* companies give easier interviews at conferences meant for underrepresented applicants. The company I’m thinking of has a much shorter interview and applicants bypass the onsites which are pretty long and rigorous. You could argue that shorter interviews aren’t necessarily easier and only increase the false-negative rate but in this case the questions asked were actually easier. This isn’t anecdotal (its firsthand) but I’ve heard this anecdotally as well. I have multiple female friends who have commented on how easy it is to get offers from *certain* companies at conferences like GHC.
This is very interesting^^thanks for sharing.

Worth noting that most/all diversity & inclusion organizations disapprove of this kind of explicit "lowering of the bar" (and instead recommend stuff like this).

I'd also find it very unlikely if this kind of bias entered into the post-interview hiring stage of an application (which would probably be illegal). Most of diversity and inclusion policies advocate for more outreach of initial applicants and/or not overlooking disadvantaged applicants for the initial code screen/interview.

Other people can chime in.

I don't think the content of OP's post suggests they haven't chatted with POC or women on the matter.

I think OP is discussing possible concerns that someone who is a strong candidate, could still be unfairly rejected not on merit or competition, but by some other means.

I think OP is questioning the system and is frustrated, as they state, and perhaps believes they are held to a much higher standard than other candidates. So yes, your advice, in general, is fantastic, and perhaps not applicable to OP's particular concerns. If OP's concerns are valid in some way, then it's unfair to become a stronger candidate just to have an equal chance of succeeding against others who may have some secret bias.

If not picking on merit is an issue, then bringing it up and attempting to change it, is a valid way of doing so.

I can't discount POC (I am one) and women(I am not one)'s discrimination, nor can I discount OP's discrimination. I just hope all of this discrimination goes away soon.

I don't know if this is an issue of "higher standards" as much as: there's too many white/Asian guys to pick from, so to ensure a diverse workplace, the "acceptance rate" for women/POC ends up being higher than for white/Asian males. (I agree with this practice, by the way - I think diversity is important. And I believe the women/POC being hired are just as qualified, if not more so, than the white/Asian males.)

Nonetheless, OP's frustration is justified, even if the beliefs informing his opinions are not.

I'm also slightly put off by the "just change yourself" narrative - yes, you can improve yourself to some degree (side projects, being less bitter, etc etc) but often it feels like you have to fit a certain mold to be accepted in certain spaces. I've noticed that in techie spaces like Silicon Valley, the people's backgrounds might be diverse, but their worldviews are remarkably similar. It's a monoculture with a rainbow of faces. How diverse are we, really?

Please go chat with women or POC and hear their perspective because I don't think you actually understand the discrimination they face? 

Also, if your recruiting isn't going well, maybe you can reflect on what you can do to become a stronger candidate! Like side-projects or attend the many professional workshops held by EECS, networking, etc. Some wise advice I've heard from a mentor: "You can't change others but you can change yourself."

OP, we don't know how life has been going for you lately, but just know you're not alone. Many of us have been rejected plenty of times, and at times, it may seem unfair, and at times, it is unfair. I get it completely.

Bounce back from this though. Keep applying, getting that killer resume, brush up on some skills, and keep at it. Many people of all genders, religions, and ethnicities have been rejected a ton, only to come back stronger through resilience and hard work, to succeed. Don't give up.

I can't speak on what goes on in companies and how they decide to recruit, I do know there are regulations and laws in place, but keep at it. At least for this semester, much won't change, so you gotta just keep grinding to get an internship/job(assuming you are looking for one).
"Google Finds It’s Underpaying Many Men as It Addresses Wage Equity": https://www.nytimes.com/2019/03/04/technology/google-gender-pay-gap.html

I am sympathetic with OPs views (and I will make a followup saying why) but the linked article is poor evidence of discrimination against men if you read past the headline.

Google did not account for whether women are being assigned levels appropriate with their experience and whether women are being promoted as quickly as men for their work. 

To address the first concern, you can resubmit hiring committee paperwork with any gendered information redacted and see if you observe higher leveling for the women. I thought Google already did this but does anyone else want to chime in?

I don't believe this type of discrimination is happening in the workplace but I am curious to hear OP explain why he thinks women/POC are getting better offers considering that statical reports from ANY company shows the exact opposite when you look at pay broken down by race and gender...

Low representation does not mean discrimination.. Do women dominated professions like nursing/schoolteaching discriminate against men? Does the NBA discriminate against whites and asians? Sometimes we just need the best person for the job. Unfortunately companies do lower the bar for more "diversity". I've personally witnessed this, where an engineer was specifically hired for this purpose.

I wouldn't take anything Tim Apple is saying seriously. He's doing a terrible job of running Apple and is still living off the dividends of Steve Jobs.
Tim Apple LOLOL

To the person above why do you assume that the hiring bar is lowered across the industry? Your one instance where you perceive that someone was hired for diversity is not fact. Also where in my post did I claim explicit discrimination? The only person making these claims are the OP. I am countering by saying there is a) no reverse discrimination and b) your post is extremely insensitive. When you say “sometimes we need the best person for the job” and put diversity in quotes it is completely disrespectful. Not sure why you are comparing to the nursing industry and the NBA at all in this scenario. It seems like a straw man argument because I ever mentioned that anyone was being explicitly discriminated against.

(not OP) but I believe they make a fair point with the NBA example. Its player demographic is > 75% African American, and we never hear complaints about (a lack of) diversity or anything like that. That's probably because they solely focus on a player's merit and not discriminating on any other factor. I think OP is saying that the tech industry and colleges too should use this as the traditional metric rather than pandering to the issue of "diversity".

There are also plenty of women-dominated professions, as mentioned above, and we don't really hear too much about diversity there either. Just my 2 cents, I'm not arguing for one side or another here but it is worth thinking about.

(not OP) Many companies and universities simply use diversity as an agenda to improve their own reputation. I am not arguing against POC and women entering tech industries, but the way to achieve diversity shouldn't be to lower the admission standards. The way to do it is to improve technology education for these groups starting from elementary school, so they will be able to compete after entering college level. For many universities, you can take a look at the SAT scores of Asian applicants and find out that they have to score 300 points more than other minorities to even be considered for admission. And when it comes to applying for technology industries, women usually have a much higher chance of getting an interview(For many of my friends, the chance to get an interview is all they need. Because what follows is simply talking about projects or answering algorithm questions, which is very easy for them who take 4 hardcore tech classes each semester, with a 3.9+ GPA and have done countless side projects and hundreds of algorithm questions.) But most of them only get 1/5 of the interview opportunities of POC or women, who sometimes are clearly less qualified. We never talk about diversity in NBA(with the majority of them being black), we never talk about diversity in firefighters or police officers(with the majority of them being men), and we never barely talk about diversity in terms of class or financial abilities. Being political correct doesn't necessarily mean being right.

You should read some of the posts below. They got some good stuff on why diversity is important in the workplace and why recruiters want that. That's not to say companies and universities don't use diversity as an agenda to improve their own reputation, I agree with you there and I wish this would stop. I just don't think it's as many as you may think/you're undervaluing the underrepresented experience. If you're not as skilled as someone else, what else can you bring to the table? For colleges, they look at what tools you were born with/had around you and how did you use them. While I agree that improving education from elementary school is a better resolve than what we have now, level the playing field, it's unfortunately not realistic as an immediate solution/lots of politics around this.

Privilege also plays a huge aspect on how you succeed (by privilege, I mean sex, sexuality, class/wealth, culture/race, etc.) You think it's unfair that POCs and women are getting these jobs? How unfair is it that the privileged have an easier time of obtaining success (nice house, fancy schools, nowhere near the poverty line, nowhere near danger, etc.)? On a grand scale, the sum of disadvantages the unprivileged deal with is greater on the sum of the disadvantages the privileged face. Those privileged should be grateful they don't have to deal with some of the stuff unprivileged people must go through.

You have to dig underneath the surface than these examples you provided. I'm not trying to go super deep, because any one of these you can talk tremendously about and argue back and forth. But my point is that these examples are not so black and white as you're making it sound:

Blacks in the NBA still have to work hard and deal with a bunch of hardship others privileged don't have to face. Plus they have a whole history of blacks being used and discriminated in the NBA. You can't discount the context. The NBA (and anything sports related for that matter) tries to make things look well and will distort whatever they need to for the sake of their image. Also, how often do you hear about women sports? Do you know about women representation on ESPN or any other big sports media? All sports mainly care about money.

Police officers and doctors are shown as men in American culture. When you think of an officer, firefighter, or doctor, do you imagine a male or female (doctors we're getting better at, but the stereotype is that males are doctors and females are nurses. Power dynamics also doesn't help with this [which the anon who talked professors above should look in to] but I'm getting myself a little too deep now). Getting reenforced that you're qualified for a job helps plant a seed for some of your inspiration. It opens your mind to that opportunity, that option.

Also, what do you mean you don't hear diversity in terms of class or financial abilities? What circles are you in? See if these circles around you are privileged. There are definitely people who care and talk about class and income tremendously as it highly affects their lives. The SAT is a classist test. MCAT and med-school is designed to disfavor the poor (who has money to live for 3 months studying for an exam full time? Not the poor). The tech industry doesn't talk about it because they're not in that circle. With so much money flowing through the field, how can you be poor? It's very hard for the rich to relate to the poor.

Let's first talk about diversity in workforce and universities.

   The main argument for gender diversity and racial diversity in the workforce is that people with different races and genders create a diversified environment, allowing different types of thoughts to flourish. And sometimes that bring innovative solutions to problems. But there is no discussion of how enforcing racial and gender quota on admission helps to create that environment. In fact, qualified engineers, each with sufficient skills and profound knowledge of the materials, can build innovative products despite them having the same race and gender. Examples can be found in the rising Chinese technology giants. Almost all of the engineers working in companies like Huawei, Alibaba, Tencent, ByteDance or Baidu are of Chinese origin. (They are all Asians.) Compared to politically correct U.S. companies, they don't have a diversified environment. However, they are spreading new 5G technologies, building fantastic games, maintaining billion-user apps and creating many innovative products. Two Asian males, who are both qualified for the work, are in no way less innovative than an Asian working with a Black. Each individual, even from the same race and gender, grows up differently, thinks differently, and has different approaches to problems. ENFORCING gender and racial diversity in a company doesn't necessarily bring innovation to the company. What it does is to create a good image of the company, making their costumers feel good about its products. I mean, no company wants to be politically incorrect in public. That is just commercial suicide.

   With that being said, what truly helps an industry the most, is to hire people based on only their academic and industrial achievements, giving interviews to people who impress them with their abilities, not their race and gender. That is what I think the OP supports, the traditional merit-based system.

   To clarify, I am never arguing against women or POC other than Asians entering tech industry. I am arguing that they should be held the same standard as Asian and White males. What really hurts innovation and progress, it to recruit underrepresented people who don't possess the same skills as their peers. In fact, it is perfectly normal for a female engineer to be as qualified, if not even more so, than a male engineer. I have seen countless examples of friends of mine, who are amazing female engineers. I also have TAs who are POC other than Asian, that I believe are clearly qualified for any technology industry. No one should ever question their qualification to get the jobs they deserve. However, many "underrepresented" people, clearly without such skillsets, also get way more interview opportunities than white/asian males who work much harder than they do. The reason for this is because currently, tech companies can't find enough qualified "underrepresented" individuals to boost their image. They have to do some "diversity hire" to reach their quota. I hope that with improved educational system, one day the companies don't have to enforce a quota to hire enough "unprivileged". But before that day comes, hiring "underrepresented" individuals who are not as competent as their peers is REVERSE DISCRIMINATION. 

  You can argue that these individuals are unprivileged in terms of race and gender. That even though they are not as competent, they deserve to be rewarded for the injustice done to them. But the way to do it is not to HURT the Asian males, who have never in history contributed to any of the unjust policies.

   And when it comes to universities, by saying that affirmative action is illegal so we don't consider race in admission is really hypocritical to me. (I am definitely not responding to one of the posts above. In my opinion, Cal has done an amazing job of accepting people based on merit, not race and gender.) To support this claim, the university in question should release the data of the following: SAT scores/GPA of all the admitted students from different races, and observe whether there is a clear difference between different races. In Havard, Asian students have to earn more than 300 points on SAT to get the same chance of admission as Black students. You can argue that Asians are simply not charismatic as students from other races, that they have inferior personalities. But please give me a valid reason for this statement, because this is something I find hard to accept. When I mentioned "we barely talk about diversity in terms of class or financial abilities", I am not saying that it doesn't matter. On the contrary, I am saying that it deserves more attention! We heard about affirmative action protects people from underrepresented groups in terms of race and gender. What about financial status? Have the private universities supported enough poor families? Do they ever give a quota s.t. only 50% of the admitted students should come from top rich families? Interestingly, they talk every day about their diversity, how they accept people from all races. But they never talk about how many poor people they accept, how they give the poor students a chance to get better education. (Cal does great in this regard. Go bears! But the universities I have in mind are really hypocritical in this regard, in my opinion)

   Now I will talk about diversity in a broader sense. What I am arguing is, if we want diversity, then we should talk about diversity in all professions. We say that there are not enough women CEOs and engineers, which I totally agree. Women really do have a hard time break the glass ceiling. But we should also talk about firefighters and police officers. These are the professions that endanger the life of employees. We are perfectly happy to let the working environment in these professions be male-dominant. And we don't think that's an issue. Because men are more physically equipped than women to handle danger? I don't think so. I think there should also be diversity programs in these professions. About NBA, I will never deny how hard the black players work, how much social pressure they face. But we never talk about diversity in NBA. Why is that? So it is OK to not have enough Asians in NBA, but it's totally against the rules of diversity to have not enough black people in technology industries. Yet the media coverage focus heavily on the latter, and barely on the former. 

   In my mind, I sincerely hope for a world in which we are never judged on what we are born with, where we come from, what race and gender we have, but only our merits and virtues. However, a limited scope of diversity is a reverse discrimination against certain groups. And diversity should never becomes the reason we give up on more qualified individuals.

First, I don't believe that companies will lower their hiring bar to meet some quota for certain races/genders. Also, where is your evidence of better offer packages? If you have concrete evidence of these please feel free to share (all your sources look like lawsuits against big tech companies). Anecdotally, I haven't seen any reverse discrimination in tech. Women already have low representation see this article here and infographic here, and from my experience out of four internships all of my past teams have been 100% male and in the intern classes women/PoC have been the minority. Just look at the gender disparity within EECS (22% female in 2017 compared to 11% in 2010). Can you imagine how it feels as a woman/PoC reading this post and making it seem like your accomplishments are not due to merit? They need to pass the same interviews as you do. As a CS/EECS grad coming out of Berkeley you should have more than enough opportunities presented to you so that you don't have to ask or whine about reverse discrimination. In my opinion instead of complaining it would be more prudent to work on gaining more skills and improving your resume to make you a better candidate.

Also here is a quote from Apple CEO Tim Cook on why diversity in the workplace is important: "I think the U.S. will lose its leadership in technology if this doesn't change. Women are such an important part of the workforce. If STEM-related fields continue to have this low representation of women, then there just will not be enough innovation in the United States. That's just the simple fact of it." [source]

For people who believe in reverse discrimination, what is the solution in your opinion?

For people who believe in female and POC discrimination, what is the solution in your opinion?

For people who believe there is no discrimination for females and POC, but simply low representation, what is the solution in your opinion?
thank you for this
Well said.

(Disclaimer: am Asian male from a relatively privileged background - suburban, great school district, etc. Am not from the Bay btw)

I've definitely been incredibly academically privileged in my life - went to an intense high school that prepared me really well for Berkeley, and I've excelled bc of it.

First, I agree with everything you said. And you have every right to be pissed off about this post, for all the reasons you described.

But I also empathize with OP's frustration. Felt this a lot when applying to colleges too. No matter our background, we're taught that hard work pays off - and even if people like me and OP have been given incredible privileges in life, we've still had to work incredibly hard to get to where we are now. We've made incredible sacrifices just to get to Berkeley - social life, sleep, and unfortunately, sometimes mental health. Often, it feels like that hard work is not paying off. Our burdens are very different in nature, but it's hard to quantify whose struggles are worse - it's a value judgment, and lots of other factors, like family dynamics or support networks, can ease or intensify our stress.

Most of the women/POC I've worked with are incredibly talented, often the best you can find in the room. However, tech still attracts mostly white/Asian men because of lots of societal factors that we're well aware of. The dilemma arises when there's a cap on how many people are allowed into a certain space, and there's many more qualified people than there are spots. In these cases, companies/colleges/etc will choose to diversify that space instead of making it 100% reflective of the applicant pool. This is fine to me, and is better than the alternative - I 100% agree that diversity of perspective is beneficial and necessary, so that the things we make benefit everyone. That said, I hope you can see how for white and Asian men, this can be a frustrating position to be in - we're denied opportunities to use our skills to contribute to society solely because there are too many people like us.

I'm much more educated about these issues, and in a much better place, than senior year of high school when I was rejected by every college I applied to that used affirmative action and accepted by every college that didn't. I've been fairly successful in achieving my goals and am satisfied with my life. And OP could certainly seem to benefit from new perspectives. But no matter how well you understand what's going on, this can still be a frustrating position to be in. Just as OP should think about other perspectives, I ask that you keep OP's perspective in mind as well. Phrases like "Are these the people we're training?", to me, reflect a fundamental disdain and lack of empathy for people like OP. Maybe OP doesn't know about the struggles of others; that's not entirely on him. But now, he knows better.

I disagree with OP's ideas and agree with yours. And I don't claim to understand your struggles as an underrepresented POC, since I was never in that position. But this absolutely feels like an attack on OP's character, and we've seen time and time again that that never changes people's minds, it only entrenches their beliefs further.

If you made it this far, thanks for reading.

PS

I'd just like to add that I hate the way affirmative action (AA) and corporate diversity are used to pit Asians against other POC (just look at the Harvard trial). As POC, we all have our own struggles living in a white-dominated society, and for those white elites looking to preserve their own power, they love nothing more than to see POC communities squabbling with each other over things like AA. (Not to mention how insulting it can be to underrepresented populations - see the "lowering the bar" convo a few followups above. "oH, YoU mUsT Be tHE dIVerSitY PicK")

To me, the way AA and corporate diversity are used now, it's just paying lip service to social injustices without solving any real problems. This is especially clear when you look at socioeconomic status (class) in addition to race. (I once read an interesting argument that AA actually benefits white women the most - it flew in the face of what I thought I knew about AA so much that I didn't read more into it. But just wanted to throw this out there)

"for those white elites looking to preserve their own power, they love nothing more than to see POC communities squabbling with each other over things like AA"

Who are you referring to? Please be specific. This is a polite way of saying I disagree with you and I think its a mistake to assume such extreme nefarious intentions to (white) people who oppose the kind of affirmative action practiced by private universities. I mean seriously, this sounds conspiratorial and I have no idea why you would say this.

Original anon of this thread. Thanks for replying and understanding, not an easy subject to reply to overall.

I wanted to clarify my response on "Are these the people we're training." This is more of a call to action on the department. Within the past couple of years there have been some serious screw-ups in the tech world (Google misclassifying blacks, "The Gaydar", etc.). If we're not training people to be empathetic (which btw, is a VERY hard skill to have), you're more likely to hurt people and be less conscious of it. Other departments have required science and tech ethics classes. Why aren't we moving forward into this? The rest of the world is not this bubble of privilege. I just wish this school did a better job of teaching that in the sciences (than having to rely on students to voice their opinions and educate others).

I'm not trying to play the who-worked-harder-game. But on my side of the spectrum, I've been denied positions because I didn't have the qualifications that people with greater opportunity could afford (for jobs and schools). Applying to the Ivy Leagues, I remember one interviewer asked me to give an example of something I did that benefited a community or group. When I told him I was in charge of successfully hiring my college counselor at my school, he told me that wasn't good enough. Then preceded to tell me an example about another interviewee he had that was going to the olympics for figure skating and all the charity work and inspiration she had done to her fanbase...

This is the most I can sympathize for the OP. I didn't choose to grow up POC, and neither did those with privileged backgrounds. I don't know what it's like being Asian nor having money/opportunities growing up. But I do know what it's like being denied because of something you're born with, which is something the OP and you expressing. We all had to work hard given the tools we were born with to get here. But you have to understand that if you grew up privileged, you have more of a chance of making it/success than POCs did. When you experience something outside your privilege comfort zone, you get frustrated? You think it's unfair? I've had to deal with being uncomfortable all my life. That's a slap to my face. This is what gets me angry. As a privileged individual, you have a lot of power. Use it to expand your mind, not close it, not to blame others. I sincerely hope the OP has learned something through these posts.

I personally don't believe racial AA works all that well. I think socioeconomic status plays a HUGE role in your outcome in life. I rather not get into this as this is a whole other discussion.

@2 anons above:

Legacy admits. I think we can all agree that these are some of the least deserving candidates to get into "top" schools, but you really don't see any policies aimed at eliminating that "backdoor". While some legacy admits are qualified, many are not - I've heard many stories of these kinds of students (lazy/don't try in school, drive fancy cars, parents donated/were alums, etc). And I'm sorry if this rubs you the wrong way, but just based on my observations, most of these kids are white.

And I don't think these kinds of people gather in a dark room and go "how can we screw over everyone else" - it's just that there's a system in place, often set up before they were born, that favors them, and they don't think about it at all. And those who do think about it keep quiet - they certainly won't be advocating to dismantle a system that gives them a leg up.

I admit it does sound conspirational, but I didn't have time to elaborate - we're all students and lead busy lives :/ but I stand by my position

@original anon:

I've felt a lot of the same, with regards to your experiences looking for opportunities.

But it seems you feel that if we're "privileged", we have no right to get frustrated or complain about unfairness. Unfairness? Sure, we could definitely use some perspective - we absolutely do have a much better shot at "making it". And I've gained a lot of perspective since starting school at Cal.

But I think everyone has a right to be frustrated if they encounter things that frustrate them, no matter how ridiculous it might seem to others. Frustration is a natural human emotion that can arise from all sorts of triggers. If you shame people for feeling things, that only leads to resentment. It festers, and then you get posts like OP's.

Perspective is what heals frustration (at least to me). And I get it - why should we be responsible for educating OP when he could take the initiative and open his mind himself? Really tough question, I don't have a good answer to that. But yeah, I really hope OP's learned something through this experience.

Original anon of thread here:

I agree, you're right. You're welcome to feel frustrated. Who am I to say you can't feel something?

What bothers me is the inconsideration and the comments made by the OP. People are hurt, I'm hurt. Reading the OP's comments and how some people have responded today has affected my sleep and schooling today. 

Yeah, I'm with you. I really do hope the OP learned something today.

This is probably one of the most revolting posts I've ever seen on a Piazza page. I can't believe this is posted and almost no one else has said anything about this. I'm extremely pissed. You're bordering hating a group of people my friend, so watch what you say. (Esspecially about the reparations tax. Really? This is so insulting to me. Do you think a monetary payment is enough to justify my life experiences? Do you think the Japanese Americans were happy with the reparation payment they received after their treatment in the internment camps?)

I'm sorry but you don't understand the sexism nor racism (nor classism) that exists out there. You have no idea how much of a disadvantage people like me (a POC) have when applying to these jobs. The amount of trauma some of us must go through, cultural differences, socioeconomic disadvantages, conditioned discouragement, isolationism, lack of mentors or role models. I've been discriminated at almost half of the Berkeley career fairs I've gone to, simply because of how I look.

While I'm not trying to invalidate your experience, you should at least try to understand why diversity is important rather than put a blame on a certain group of people. I'll give you this, some people want to hire diversity for the sake of diversity and "looking good". They're making diversity into a fad with this connotation. This is bad, and I agree with you that this is not okay. However choosing to hire for a variety of perspectives isn't a bad thing.

The point of diversity is about getting different types of people in a room who think a certain, yet different way. Ask recruiters why they care about diversity, (I have, and the good ones usually say this:) you don't want a room of 1 certain type of thought and of one certain type of person, do you? If you can bring a different type of positive mindset into the room, thinking outside the box, you're already standing out. You can bring an opinion to the table that can benefit the company that no one else has. You're valuable when it comes to this.

While yes, this is probably an advantage over the over-represented in tech, and probably what you're pointing out, do you have any idea how much of an advantage and opportunity the privileged over-represented have over the under-represented. Were there coding opportunities in your middle/high schools? Were you ever hired a tutor? How much did your parents care about your education/success? Did the rest of your neighborhood go to college? This is stuff people take for granted that make a difference in how you succeed. You complaining about 1 advantage that POC people have does not sum up to the scale the privileged over-represented have. Do you know how insulting that is to me?

And do POCs really get better offers? Do some more research than just the sources you've put up. Don't bias it up. There's mountains of studies, statistics, and research about this stuff. 

My 2 cents: Take an ethics class. Learn about how privileged you are in life. Learn about the weight you don't have to carry. It's better to learn now then have a screw up later in your life. 

@Moderators: Apologies for my foul language or if it seems like I'm attacking the OP. But this is a classic example of someone in STEM living in a bubble and insulting/hurting those around them. Are these the people we're training?
Very true.

I disagree with Anon. This conversation belongs here. Moving the conversation into another platform like Reddit or Facebook would quickly derail some points that all of these anons are trying to make. Anonymity can be useful in this case, because people can let out some gripes that they have that is obviously absent in bubbled communities like Reddit and Facebook (upvote/react system). OP didn't make this post out of malice, they wanted to have a conversation about discrimination (regardless of whether it is "reverse" or not) in this industry. I won't make any assumptions about the above anon, whether they are underrepresented/POC/female or not, but I do find it very disappointing that this anon chose to instead shame the OP and attack their character. 

I'm sorry for who hurt you, given that you have this belief that "every single person in this department" attributes merit to identity. I'm a POC and a male, though I don't think my identity should matter, for the same reason you mention that it just reduces my entire being to identity. I hope you can find supportive allies in this department.

Repectfully, I disagree with the notion that this conversation specifically belongs on EECS 101. It concerns a subject that is extremely difficult, and frankly triggering, for people who have been on the receiving end of these kinds of comments both implicitly and explicitly. For most students who have had these types of questions directed at their abilities, it is death by a thousand paper cuts. You're dealing with comments, suggestions, and actions from other people each and every day echoing these attitudes (and it feeds into confidence issues, imposter syndrome, and anxieties, which can further add stress onto a student). It's hard not to feel alone and unsupported in this process. I can choose to not have a reddit account, but I can't avoid using Piazza for academic purposes. This is an attitude that is sadly already present in so many aspects of campus and life (not just related to tech), and it's saddening and exhausting to have it pop up here as well. 

I firmly believe conversations about diversity, inclusion, equality, and equity have a place on this forum - that's how people can learn and grow. But to me, lines like "I've noticed women and minorities being given better offers or having an easier time finding one, usually for the sake of "diversity" (they probably want to protect themselves from discrimination lawsuits, ironically)" do not read as harmless or innocent. There is a huge difference between this post and someone asking something along the lines of "why are diversity/inclusion-focused hiring practices important?". 

Furthermore, I don't think most people on this forum who hold similar attitudes (whether intentional or not) will take the time to scroll all the way through these comments to find the helpful resources people have been kind enough to post - they'll most likely see the main post, which multiple people here have pointed out to be problematic, and continue on with their day with the wrong idea. (A pinned post of vetted resources on diversity and inclusion, or something similar, might be a good idea to help people learn more about these ideas through EECS 101.)

Also, just going to put it out there that no one should have to "find supportive allies" when the entire department is supposed to be a safe space free from discrimination and microaggressions . (Though I understand the intentions behind that statement)

It's not a huge surprise people are upset about this post. To quote one of the anons above, "When you experience something outside your privilege comfort zone, you get frustrated? You think it's unfair? I've had to deal with being uncomfortable all my life. That's a slap to my face. This is what gets me angry."

Couldn't have said it better myself.

I am the OP of the thread. I brought this topic up because this sentiment is very common in the industry, and it's brewing resentment. I did not grow up privileged, and I will not "check my privilege" as you are telling me. Privilege has no color. And I will never be sympathetic to those who use their racial background or sex to claim "woe is me". The matter of fact is that a growing number of companies, for better or worse, are favoring non-asian minorities or women so they can calim they are "diverse" and to right wrongs we never had anything to do with. And I will always be resentful of those who got those opportunities purely because of their "diverse" racial background or race.

If you "will always be resentful of those who got those opportunities purely because of their "diverse" racial background or race" when so many people on this thread have tried to explain why that has never been the case (diversity is a factor in the hiring process, but no one in this industry ever gets hired solely for diversity), then you have clearly missed the point of this entire discussion.

I feel sorry for all the people who devoted time to share alternate perspectives and try to educate you when it seems to be that you had made up your mind before you even posted.

^

yo OP I've defended your right to be frustrated a LOT in this thread, but not gonna lie that's really disappointing to hear. It really does seem like you'd made up your mind before you posted. Now I feel like a fool for wasting all this time.

Whatever's going on in your head, I hope it clears up soon. I've been where you are, and trust me, it's much better on the other side. Sometimes you just have to let go of things

I am the OP of this thread. I was replying to the original poster of this comment chain. I was open to hearing the other side, but he/she immediately called to silence this discussion by moving it elsewhere. I guess "diversity" is good but not free speech? If he/she won't be tolerate of my views (which aren't uncommon), why should I be tolerate of anyone else's?

^^ yeah OP you lost me here. The point of this thread is to share different perspectives and come up with a new understanding, but your unwillingness to change is your downfall. Really disappointing to hear.

(OP of this followup) Asking to move a subject that is triggering for some people to another space that might be better suited for such discussions  =/= being intolerant of free speech. One of the follow-up comments clearly talks about healthy conversations around diversity and inclusion being important to include on EECS101, but clearly this post was never intended to fall into that category. Thanks for making that clear.

OP I understand your frustrations, i'm really sorry you feel this way. You are definitely entitled to your free speech, and I personally think it's fine to keep these conversations here.

Given your response, I think it's best to just keep working hard and keep trying. Once you get w/e you're applying for, see if you can meet with certain recruiters or counselors and voice your opinion to them, if you would like to change the system you believe is unfair towards you.

I sincerely wish you well, and really hope you end up getting the job you really want after graduation. Keep posting on EECS 101 if you ever need advice on topics or want to continue venting about things like rejections. 

Finally, I want to bring up something you said:

"And I will never be sympathetic to those who use their racial background or sex to claim "woe is me"."

I hope you reconsider, because this is exactly what you are doing.

For the love of all that is holy, can this conversation please be moved off of Piazza and onto some other platform (ex Reddit or Facebook). It's exhausting enough to go through this department and industry dealing with all the challenges of being underrepresented. It's not fair to also expect students from underrepresented minorities to perform the additional labor of educating those who directly invalidate our lived experiences when a simple google search can turn up a boatload of research and statistics and data showing that the reality is far different from the cherrypicked links included above.

You talk about Google underpaying men. But you don't mention Google's $135M payout to executives who abused their power and sexually harassed employees (how much do you want to bet those employees got an NDA rather than a multi-million dollar check?).  You don't mention Pao vs. Kleiner Perkins, Uber whistleblower Susan Fowler, or any one of the hundreds of thousands of stories of minorities who have experienced many horrible things in this industry (and of course, you would have no way of knowing about the countless stories that are only shared behind closed doors with other minorities/POC to warn each other about bad companies and be supported by each other, rather than risk the backlash and carry the weight/trauma of sharing our experiences on a public stage where we are far more likely to be ridiculed and questioned rather than supported and believed.)

Ask any one of your classmates who identify with an underrepresented background whether they think they've benefitted from "reverse discrimination". I would bet good money they'll all give you a story of actual discrimination and microaggressions they've experienced instead. (Spoiler alert, reverse discrimination is not a thing, @every single person in this department, not just OP, who has ever insinuated our identities are the reasons we get internships,etc. rather than the literal blood, sweat, and tears we put into everything we do).

Or better yet - do your own research rather than expecting additional emotional labor from groups who already are expected to give up so much just to pursue this field. Here, I'll do you one favor and give you a starting point: https://www.ncwit.org/resources

No company "lowers their bar" for minority candidates. We usually have to perform so undeniably well and perform so much better than the bar to prove our worth, and prove that "it wasn't just a lucky guess". And then we are questioned each and every single day as to whether we are truly qualified because of all the people around us who think we were "just the diversity hire to avoid lawsuits". Here's a question for you - if companies are practicing "reverse discrimination" to avoid diversity lawsuits, why is every minority group still so absurdly underrepresented?

Want to know why recruiters will "chase after" minority candidates? It's because if they're still kicking butt in this industry after experiencing so many hurdles each and every day and overcoming all of these challenges, that means they are probably the most ridiculously over-qualified, talented, and emotionally intelligent individual around. It means they're the type of candidate any recruiter worth their salt would chase after, regardless of race. (And odds they're still going to be underpaid and underpromoted even after getting hired? Extremely high)

Shame on you for masking your ignorance and personal frustrations under the protection of anonymity and the guise of curiosity. Shame on you for continuing to perpetuate these myths that make life harder for so many of us. Shame on you for choosing to remain uneducated (yes, considering how easy it is to learn about these topics on the Internet, it is in fact an active choice to remain ignorant). But thanks for the reminder that this department, and frankly the entire industry, still has a long way to go in terms of truly supporting students who don't look and sound like the Marks and Bills and Evans of the world.

“When you're accustomed to privilege, equality feels like oppression.”

I do want to add to this conversation that I am happy with all the diversity programs aimed to educate and promote inclusiveness for certain groups like certain races and ethnic groups, females, under-resourced youth.

I am a first generation American whose parents make poverty level income, and I am a minority. We are blessed to live in government assisted housing, otherwise we'd probably be living in a cramped 1 bedroom lol. I'm not a typical minority(AA, NA, Latino, Female), but I understand my struggles and appreciate companies are taking action to promote diversity and bring students to their campuses to educate and make under-represented people feel like the company is an attainable goal.

In terms of whether companies discriminate against minorities, I don't know. In terms of whether companies discriminate against white/indians/asians etc, I don't know. The law says discrimination is illegal, i'm sure there are ways around the law. If a company benefits economically, who knows what they would do.

But regardless of what happens in recruiting, and whether diversity of races, ethnicities, genders, religions actually produce better results and a better work environment.....i'm just happy for the improvement.

Many years ago, certain people weren't allowed to eat in the same restaurant. Many years ago, females weren't allowed to work. Many years ago, i'd be afraid of telling people my ethnicity. We're improving.

And yes, I have huge empathy for the struggles POC and women go through. I've heard many stories from their perspectives and many of their struggles are not as simple as "oh you're a girl/poc, we will discourage or not hire you". And yes, I have huge empathy for the people who feel like they are now being discriminated against because there is an abundance of their ethnicities and skin color in tech. I've seen these people have great resumes, great skills, and just keep getting rejected(I don't know why they got rejected and won't speculate).

But in conclusion, I hope we continue uplifting and educating everyone, with, at times, separate conferences and groups catered to certain ethnic groups and genders. I hope we do not blame peer women and POC for the reason we get rejected. And I hope women and POC don't blame peer (everyone else?) for their struggles as well. It might be the older people who discriminate, or the systems that discriminate, but we can work and support one another by not pointing the finger, but rather, cheering for their success, and continuing to fight your fight to get what you want.

Then, if you feel discriminated against, fight to change that system. I think we all want a system based on merit, but I also want a system that uplifts everyone through conferences/tours/informational-interviews, including POC, women, and Asians/Indians/Whites etc.

I'll end with this. Yes, I am flawed in that I didn't believe I could make it in the tech industry because of my ethnicity and background. I thought I was too dumb. Even when I got internship offers, I thought it was a fluke, and I thought I would be fired from my internship for sucking.

Then I went to a conference dedicated to my ethnicity. I used to think we were all living in poverty. But no. Entrepreneurs, CEO's, Doctors, Lawyers, Software Engineers, Product Managers, Consultants, Singers, Dancers, Rappers, Marketers, these people were 5-15 years older than me, and I saw all their successes and how they overcame obstacles just like I am right now. It empowered me, and I keep in contact with these people, and know that no matter how much I fail and how much the world's rules work against me....I will succeed.

Some companies partner with nonprofits,etc that specifically serve underrepresented/low income individuals! Those programs tend to ask for FAFSA (or equivalent)- type of information in their applications and such. :)

Off the top of my head the only one I can think of is Apple’s partnership with TMCF (which does sort of have a racial component to it because it targets HBCU students, but that’s intersecfionality for ya). https://www.tmcf.org/our-programs/career-preparation/apple-tmcf-hbcu-initiative

Has anyone heard of any tech companies that have programs focused on people with low income backgrounds, regardless of whether or not they are a racial minority in the industry? I've never really heard of such a thing and I get the feeling that it's impossible to verify such a thing without FAFSA-style auditing, which no company would likely want to be doing.

Problem is that affirmative action policies actively discriminate against Asians, who had nothing to do with white people's historically institutional racism against blacks. Affirmative action "diversity" hires pit minorities against each other while white people feel better about themselves even though they are still on top. What we need is a reparations tax on white people instead of this affirmative action "diversity" hiring nonsense.
http://leftycartoons.com/2008/07/10/a-concise-history-of-black-white-relations-in-the-united-states/

Thank you to everyone who took the time to share their thoughts and POVs! Here’s an interesting event I wanted to share that is related to what we can do as students in regards to the imperfect practices with recruitment/networking: 

Bias Busters and GEESE are hosting a discussion of tech ethics, hiring practices, and how we can put pressure on tech companies through recruitment and networking events on Thursday, April 4th at 6 PM in Cory 540A/B. We want to invite a broad range of voices to discuss these important issues.

We propose the following discussion topics:

  • What is our responsibility as students / tech workers?

  • How do we assess tech company ethical practices?

  • Opportunities for student action, such as:

    • petition for reporting diversity statistics

    • awareness for career fair attendees

    • promoting ethical companies for recruitment events


Rsvp here: https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSfc95Ro6cjwtrq2Bzyxh-Ht8u-XcPrpmW9wrh8d8faHT9-y5g/viewform?usp=sf_link

history.content:
Anybody notice the growing trend of reverse discrimination in hiring? At the big companies at least, I've noticed women and minorities being given better offers or having an easier time finding one, usually for the sake of "diversity" (they probably want to protect themselves from discrimination lawsuits, ironically). For example, recruiters will chase tails if the person is a person of color (unfortunately Asians don't count as PoC in this case) or a woman. Some companies have explicitly been told to cap the number of white male and asian male applicants (the latter doesn't even make any sense, since asians are actually quite underprivileged. imagine being a poor asian discriminated by affirmative action when applying to college, only to have the same thing happen now when you're applying for a job lol).I understand sexism and racism in the industry exists, but it's frustrating to see this kind of slimy reverse discrimination happening. I mean if you want to balance out inequities, this is not the way to do it. Even paying reparations would be a better way (maybe a reparations tax on certain races). Also don't do the reverse discrimination behind closed doors and then try to hide it, just say it outright.

 

I'm sorry, I'm just frustrated. I understand non-Asian PoC and women have suffered from discrimination, but it doesn't make sense to inflict the same thing on other groups who had nothing to do with the hurdles they felt in the first place.

 

Sources:

https://www.theverge.com/2018/3/2/17070624/google-youtube-wilberg-recruiter-hiring-reverse-discrimination-lawsuit

https://www.mercurynews.com/2018/03/01/google-job-quotas-favored-women-blacks-latinos-over-white-and-asian-men-lawsuit/

https://www.sfgate.com/news/article/Yahoo-lawsuit-Marissa-Mayer-discrimination-men-9926263.php

"Google Finds It’s Underpaying Many Men as It Addresses Wage Equity": https://www.nytimes.com/2019/03/04/technology/google-gender-pay-gap.html
